title: 'I have some gas left in the tank': At 37, Djokovic still has big tennis goals
description: Djokovic has had a rough start to 2025, but shown flashes of brilliance too. And he's aiming for that 100th tour win.
author: Simon Cambers

title: Ukraine seals spot in Billie Jean King Cup Finals
description: Elina Svitolina sent Ukraine to the Billie Jean King Cup Finals for the first time with a 6-4, 6-2 win over Switzerland's Jil Teichmann to level the countries' qualifier 1-1 Saturday in Radom, Poland, a victory that also ensured Ukraine would top Group E.

title: Unlock the Perfect Slice Serve - Essential Tennis Podcast #415
description: The wide slice serve is a CRITICAL tool to have in your tool box. It pulls opponents out of position, opens the court up for you to hit into, exposes their usually weaker backhand side, and forces them to run twice as far for the next shot - if they even get it at all. Let’s take a deep dive into how YOU can develop this powerful weapon, step by step in this special episode of the Essential Tennis Podcast.
author: Essential Tennis LLC

title: 3 Djokovic Secrets To Winning More Matches - Essential Tennis Podcast #414
description: In this special episode of the Essential Tennis Podcast, you're going to learn the top 3 tactical secrets of Novak Djokovic that you can apply in your very next match. Use these tools to gain precision, consistency, and offense to make your opponents more uncomfortable, win more points, and win more matches.
author: Essential Tennis LLC

title: 'We gave it our all' - Boulter & Burrage secure GB's spot in BJK Cup Finals
description: Katie Boulter and Jodie Burrage produce a superb doubles performance to help Great Britain beat the Netherlands 2-1 and reach the Billie Jean King Cup Finals.

title: Boulter and Burrage send Great Britain into Billie Jean King Cup Finals
description: Watch the moment Katie Boulter and Jodie Burrage beat Suzan Lamens and Demi Schuurs of the Netherlands to secure Great Britain's place in September's Billie Jean King Cup Finals.

title: From Bjorn to Leo: Like father, like son
description: The apple doesn’t fall far from the tree, as they say. The name Borg is one of the most revered in the history of the ATP Tour, thanks to the legendary career of Bjorn Borg in the 70s and early 80s. Five decades later, his son Leo is trying to write his own story in the world of tennis. Borg won his two trophies at the Barcelona Open Banc Sabadell in 1975 and 1977. The road to his first trophy began against Briton John Feaver and his other victims on the clay included big names such as Jan Kodes (quarter-finals), Guillermo Vilas (semi-finals) and Adriano Panatta (final). 50 years after his triumph, his son Leo Borg is back on the same stage to make his bow at the ATP 500 in Barcelona. His appearance, despite being in the qualifiers, saw him face a player of the same nationality against which his father began his participation in 1975. This time around, the British Jacob Fearnley was on the other side of the net. So, the name ‘Borg’ was back in the draw at the Catalan event. This time around, though, the ‘Ice Man’ was in the stands keeping an eye on his son as he took his first steps at the tournament. Although Leo failed to progress, losing 7-5, 7-6(1) to Fearnley, it was one more experience on tour under the belt of the youngster. Despite the 11 Grand Slam titles and 100 weeks Bjorn spent at the top of the PIF ATP Rankings, he is not Leo’s greatest tennis idol; step up Rafael Nadal. The Spaniard, who won the Conde de Godo Trophy 12 times, lends his name to the tournament’s centre court. Just eight months ago, he had the chance to face his hero at the ATP 250 in Bastad. “It was incredible because we were watching when they made the draw and my name came out against Rafa,” the Swede said at the time of his round-one clash with the Spaniard. Leo’s adventure at ‘Nadal’s home’ and the place where his father forged a small part of his legacy came to a premature end, but once again there was a Borg hogging the limelight on the ATP Tour in Barcelona. [NEWSLETTER FORM]

title: What were the Monte-Carlo Masters results?
description: Play continued on Saturday at the Rolex Monte-Carlo Masters, where players advanced to the final in both singles and doubles. Carlos Alcaraz marched into the championship match by edging fellow Spaniard Alejandro Davidovich Fokina. Italian Lorenzo Musetti is into an ATP Masters 1000 final for the first time following his thrilling three-set win against Alex de Minaur. View all of the Saturday Monte-Carlo tennis results below.   Results - Saturday, 12 April 2025 Men's Singles - Semi-finals [2] Carlos Alcaraz (ESP) d Alejandro Davidovich Fokina (ESP) 76(2) 64 [13] Lorenzo Musetti (ITA) d [8] Alex de Minaur (AUS) 16 64 76(4) Read more: Musetti edges De Minaur in Monte-Carlo thriller, advances to first Masters 1000 final Read more: Alcaraz moves past Davidovich Fokina, reaches Monte-Carlo final Men's Doubles - Semi-finals [WC] Romain Arneodo (MON)/Manuel Guinard (FRA) d [2] Harri Heliovaara (FIN)/Henry Patten (GBR) 64 75 [7] Julian Cash (GBR)/Lloyd Glasspool (GBR) d [1] Marcelo Arevalo (ESA)/Mate Pavic (CRO) 76(2) 67(5) 10-6   [NEWSLETTER FORM]

title: Monte-Carlo Masters 2025 Day 7 Semi-Final Recap
description: Day 7 at the Rolex Monte-Carlo Masters boiled the tournament down to its final two, with Carlos Alcaraz and Lorenzo Musetti earning their spots in Sunday’s championship match. Alcaraz produced a cleaner display to oust Alejandro Davidovich Fokina in an entertaining 7-6(2), 6-4 clash, overcoming a spraying some forehands and five missed match points to …
author: Jonathan

title: Monte-Carlo Masters 2025 Day 6 Quarter Final Recap
description: Day 6 at the Rolex Monte-Carlo Masters whittled the field down to four, as the quarter-finals delivered an upset, a demolition job, a composed win, and a thrilling three-setter. In the opener, Alejandro Davidovich Fokina kept his cool, dispatching Alexei Popyrin 6-3, 6-2 to return to the semi-finals for the second time in Monte-Carlo. Carlos …
author: Jonathan
